original_data.question: An 89-year-old woman sees her neurologist for a follow-up evaluation. Three months ago, she presented with complaints about facial asymmetry. Her daughter has noticed that her mother’s mouth is droops downwards on the right side of her face and that she cannot close her right eye well. The same side also lacks wrinkles on the forehead. Since then, the patient feels like her facial muscles have gotten weaker. She was given a course of corticosteroids, but she has still not recovered fully. Upon being asked to close her eyes, the patient has difficulty doing so and fails to completely close her eyelids. On examination, there is no loss of pain, temperature, or crude or tactile touch sensations in the whole face. The neurological exam is otherwise unremarkable. This patient also has type 2 diabetes mellitus which is well controlled with metformin. The neurologist recommends a therapy that will help relieve her symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely treatment option being prescribed to this patient?

model_response:
The most likely treatment option being prescribed to this patient is 'Botox'. This patient has a Bells palsy. Bells palsy is the most common cause of acute, peripheral facial paralysis. It is usually idiopathic, but it can be associated with Lyme disease, sarcoidosis, and other underlying disorders. Patients present with acute, unilateral facial weakness or paralysis. The symptoms of Bells palsy can be very distressing to patients. The recommended treatment is prednisone (methylprednisolone) for 7-10 days. In addition, some patients may benefit from the injection of botulinum toxin (Botox) into the affected muscles. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant medication that is sometimes used to treat trigeminal neuralgia. Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic that is used to treat bacterial infections.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Congenital or acquired asymmetry of the face.
A female human offspring.
Female parents, human or animal.
The oval-shaped oral cavity located at the apex of the digestive tract and consisting of two parts: the vestibule and the oral cavity proper.
A substance intended for administration in a drop-wise fashion.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
The eye positioned in the right orbit.
A line segment forming part of the perimeter of a plane figure.
A fold, ridge or crease of the skin.
The part of the face above the eyes.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Muscles of facial expression or mimetic muscles that include the numerous muscles supplied by the facial nerve that are attached to and move the skin of the face. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
HORMONES produced by the ADRENAL CORTEX, including both steroid and peptide hormones. The major hormones produced are HYDROCORTISONE and ALDOSTERONE.
The organ of sight constituting a pair of globular organs made up of a three-layered roughly spherical structure specialized for receiving and responding to light.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Something not easily done, accomplished, comprehended, or solved.
Having undergone failure; did not accomplish the intended purpose.
Each of the upper and lower folds of SKIN which cover the EYE when closed.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Naturally occurring complex liquid hydrocarbons which, after distillation, yield combustible fuels, petrochemicals, and lubricants.
Sensation of making physical contact with objects, animate or inanimate. Tactile stimuli are detected by MECHANORECEPTORS in the skin and mucous membranes.
Including all components without exception; constituting the full amount or extent or duration; complete.
Pertaining to nerves or the nervous system.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

A type of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by insulin resistance or desensitization and increased blood glucose levels. This is a chronic disease that can develop gradually over the life of a patient and can be linked to both environmental factors and heredity.
The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.

A biguanide hypoglycemic agent used in the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus not responding to dietary modification. Metformin improves glycemic control by improving insulin sensitivity and decreasing intestinal absorption of glucose. (From Martindale, The Extra Pharmacopoeia, 30th ed, p289)

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
